Context: Jardine2*Abstract Background: Clostridium difficile is an important enteropathogen affecting humans, domestic animals, and wildlife.
In addition to humans and domestic animals, disease associated with C. difficile has been reported in a variety of wildlife species [4, 5].
Clostridium difficile can also be found in soil and water and in the intestinal tracts of apparently healthy humans and animals, including wildlife [6–8].

Further studies with larger sample sizes and more study sites that concurrently examine the occurrence of C. difficile in wildlife, livestock and the environment will help to identify potential sources of C. difficile for wildlife.
Himsworth et al. (2014) [27] found no association between season and C. difficile status in wild urban rats (Rattus spp).

Additional studies, occurring over longer time periods, with larger sample sizes, and with raccoons prior to weaning are required to better understand the seasonal and demographic factors that may be associated with C. difficile occurrence in wildlife.
